awd_titl_txt: A Big Data-Theoretic Approach to Quantify Organizational Failure Mechanisms in Probabilistic Risk Assessment
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Description
Catastrophic events such as Fukushima and Katrina have made it clear that integrating physical and social causes of failure into a cohesive modeling framework is critical in order to prevent complex technological accidents and to maintain public safety and health. In this research, experts in Probabilistic Risk Assessment (PRA), Organizational Behavior and Information Science and Data Analytics disciplines will collaborate to provide answers to the following key questions: (a) what social and organizational factors affect technical system risk? (b) how and why do these factors influence risk? and (c) how much do they contribute to risk?  Existing PRA models do not include a complete range of organizational factors. This research investigates organizational root causes of failure and models their paths of influence on technical system performance, resulting in more comprehensive incorporation of underlying organizational failure mechanisms into PRA. The field of PRA has progressed the quantification of equipment failure and human error for modeling risk of complex systems; however, the current organizational risk contributors lack reliable data analytics that go beyond safety climate and safety culture surveys. This research fills that gap by developing predictive causal modeling and big-data theoretic technologies for PRA, expanding the classic approach of data management for risk analysis by utilizing techniques such as text mining, data mining and data analytics. In addition to scientific contributions to organizational science, PRA, and data analytics, this research provides regulatory and industry decision-makers with important organizational factors that contribute to risk and leads to optimized decision making. Other applications include real-time monitoring of organizational safety indicators, efficient safety auditing, in-depth root cause analysis, and risk-informed emergency preparedness, planning and response. The multidisciplinary approach of this project can serve as an educational model, empowering students to pursue research across disciplinary boundaries.  Finally, the proposed research represents a successful model of industry-academia collaboration. A nuclear power plant has committed to this project and provides unique access to data and information necessary to complete the research. The proposed methodology is generic and applicable for any high-risk industry (e.g., aviation, healthcare, oil and gas), and will be used for the improvement of organizational safety performance in order to protect workers, the public and the environment. 

Technical Description
Organizations produce, process and store a large volume of wide-ranging, unstructured data as a result of business activities and compliance requirements (i.e., corrective action programs, root cause analysis reports, oversight and inspection data, etc.). This research leverages those data resources for the quantification of organizational failure mechanisms and their integration with the technical system risk scenarios generated by PRA. The research is based on a socio-technical risk theory to prevent misleading results from solely data-informed approaches. Combining socio-technical risk theory, systematic modeling and semantic data analytics strategies will greatly enhance risk analysis of complex systems. We will conduct our research based on following steps: (1) Expand factors, sub-factors, and causal relationships in the Socio-Technical Risk Analysis (SoTeRiA) framework, (2) Develop measurement techniques for factors, sub-factors and their causal relationships in SoTeRiA (e.g., integrating text mining with the Bayesian Belief Network; conducting scientific reduction to identify important factors; measuring of important factors), (3) Establish a dynamic, predictive socio-technical causal modeling technique, (4) Perform uncertainty analysis, (5) Conduct verification and validation, (6) Integrate the quantitative socio-technical causal model with PRA, and (7) Conduct sensitivity and importance measure analyses. As the pioneer study on the integration of big data with PRA, this research addresses and quantifies risk emerging from the interface of social and technical systems.

por.por_cntn:
Organizational factors, such as safety culture, training, leadership, and team dynamics, have contributed to the world?s most devastating accidents, such as Bhopal, Space Shuttle Columbia, Three Mile Island, Deepwater Horizon, and Fukushima. Studies in the organizational psychology and management science fields have found that organizational factors impact safety, but our understanding of how to measure and include these factors into models that help predict safety risk of complex socio-technical systems is in its infancy. Our research focuses on formally including organizational factors into models that predict risks, such as Probabilistic Risk Assessment (PRA) models.  PRA is a systematic approach to estimate the risk of failure and accidents considering scenarios emerging from a combination of equipment failure and human error. It utilizes Human Reliability Analysis (HRA) for modeling and quantifying human error by estimating the impact of issues associated with the individual worker (such as fatigue and mental overload) and the organization (such as deficiencies in teamwork and managerial factors). The integration of organizational mechanisms with HRA or PRA is challenging because it requires identifying appropriate organizational data (e.g., management actions), converting it into a numerical representation of the factor, and then estimating how much it will impact human error and equipment failure under various accident scenarios.    

Our goal was to incorporate organizational factors into risk models to predict failures more realistically and thus avoid major or catastrophic accidents more effectively.  Four key questions were addressed : (I) how significant is the contribution of organizational factors to accidents and incidents? (II) how much does the incorporation of organizational factors into PRA improve our risk estimation? (III) what theoretical bases are needed for the explicit incorporation of organizational factors into PRA? and (IV) what methods and analyses are needed to quantify the explicit incorporation of organizational factors into PRA? Answering these questions has led to improved models that help with more realistic estimation of risk and more effective prevention of failures and accidents in high-risk organizations, such as Nuclear Power Plants (NPPs).

Socio-Technical Risk Analysis (SoTeRiA) (Figure 1) was used as a framework to identify the general categories of organizational features that impact safety and risk.  These include safety culture, safety practices (e.g., training), team or group safety climate or orientation, and the individual?s views related to safety climate and orientation. These organizational categories were then used to guide our choice of what data to collect and include in risk models (i.e., PRA and HRA). An intensive series of analyses were conducted using quantitative analytics such as machine learning and natural language processing to convert organizational factors into numeric data that could then be included in HRA and PRA to estimate risks. Among all organizational factors, our work focused on the organizational training system relevant to safety, by utilizing Licensee Event Reports of U.S. NPPs. Our analysis revealed how organizational training mechanisms relevant to safety can be incorporated into risk models to predict risk more realistically in NPPs. This paves the way for future research to incorporate additional organizational factors (such as managerial decisions and actions regarding work processes in operation and maintenance of technological systems) into risk models.

This research enhances the ability of organizations to better manage technological risk by explicitly including organizational factors, in addition to equipment failure and individual human error, in their risk assessments. As a result, risks will be more clearly identified, and safety records will improve. This research integrates organizational science, advanced data analytics, and risk science to change the way industries and regulatory agencies manage organizational weaknesses and allocate resources towards mitigating organizational failure mechanisms. The enhanced organizational management enabled by this research provides the quantitative analysis necessary to improve the safety of socio-technical systems in high-consequence industries (e.g., NPPs, civil aviation, oil and gas). The results of this research will make a significant contribution to public safety by (a) explicitly assessing the technological system risk due to organizational weaknesses; (b) avoiding the underestimation of the technological risk associated with human and organizational error; (c) improving safety-related training programs in high-risk industries; and (d) identifying and ranking the critical organizational root causes of failure, which can guide in-depth data collection and corrective action programs. By enabling measurement of the impact of organizational factors on technological system risk, this research will support advancement of safeguards and regulation to protect against future failures due to organizational factors.

This project has contributed to training next-generation workforce through the educational development for students, postdocs, and researchers. The outcomes of this research have been disseminated within academia, industry and the public through conferences, workshops, and community events. The result of this research has also been taught in the PI?s undergraduate and graduate PRA courses, educating students from diverse departments.  The research team and their multidisciplinary approach served as an educational model, empowering students to pursue projects across disciplinary boundaries
